subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: Lexical sets and QS letters
msgSnippet: ... Again, it depends on where you come from.  The Deep South of the U.S. and the Midlands of England do not have HAPPY-tensing; that is, they still use [I]
messageBody:
Paul Tremblay scripsit:

> > - "happy" should never be end with #27 or anything but #26: This is
> > one of the few mandatory non-phonetic rules. How Read pronounces
> > "happy" shouldn't be inferred from this and is irrelevant anyway since
> > spelling is constant in this case.
>
> I hate this rule. I have never in my life heard anyone pronounce the
> final vowel in "happy" with #26. Using #26 is confusing and so
> counterintuitive, I wonder if it is a rule better ignored?

Again, it depends on where you come from. The Deep South of the
U.S. and the Midlands of England do not have HAPPY-tensing;
that is, they still use [I] rather than [i].

--
They tried to pierce your heart John Cowan
with a Morgul-knife that remains in the http://www.ccil.org/~cowan
wound. If they had succeeded, you would
become a wraith under the domination of the Dark Lord. --Gandalf
